title: Visualizing the Amorphous to Crystalline Transition of Bismuth Selenide in the TEM
content: Topological insulators are a special class of materials – where like a conventional insulator there exists an energy gap between the insulating and conducting bands [1]. However, unlike a conventional insulator, these energy bands are “twisted”, and as a result when transitioning to a normal insulator – these energy bands need to become “untwisted.” As a result, the interface between a topological and a conventional insulator becomes conducting as the conducting and insulating bands overlap. Since air or even vacuum are conventional insulators – the surface of a topological insulator is conducting, while the bulk of the material remains an insulator. Additionally, since the twisted energy bands are a global property of the material, this surface conducting state is insensitive to surface defects and inhomogeneities.
